title: Sorted Association - a Data Oriented Mapping
narrative:
Sprouts is a property library with a heavy focus on bridging the
    gap between classical place oriented programming and modern
    data oriented programming.
    This is why sprouts has both the `Tuple` and `Association` classes.
    The `Association` class is a value object that represents a set of
    key-value pairs. You can think of it as an immutable map, but with
    an API that is designed around transforming the data in the map
    rather than mutating it.

    A regular `Association` is unordered, meaning that the order of the
    key-value pairs is not guaranteed. But if you use special
    factory methods, you can create a `SortedAssociation` that
    guarantees the order of the key-value pairs.
    Under the hood, this key-value store is based on a binary tree
    with a node size growing with the depth of the tree.

features.id: An empty association is created by supplying the type of the key and value

code: var associations = Association.betweenSorted(String, Integer, (k1, k2) -> k1 <=> k2 )

blocks.text: We apply the operations to the associations and the map for the first time.
The associations and the map are equal in terms of size, keys, and values.
We apply the operations to the associations and the map a few more times.
The associations and the map are still equal in terms of size, keys, and values.
We can lookup any value from its corresponding key.
code: map.values() as Set == map.keySet().collect { key -> association.get(key).orElseThrow(MissingItemException::new) } as Set

blocks.text: We use the `toMap()` method to convert the association to a map.
The converted map is equal to the reference map.
We use the stream API to map both the association and the reference map.
code: var mappedAssociation = association.entrySet().stream().map({ it.withFirst(it.first().toUpperCase() + "!") }).filter({ it.hashCode() % 2 == 0 }).collect(Association.collectorOf(String, String))
var mappedMap = map.entrySet().stream().map({ Pair.of(it.key.toUpperCase() + "!", it.value) }).filter({ it.hashCode() % 2 == 0 }).collect(Collectors.toMap({it.first()}, {it.second()}))

blocks.text: The mapped association and map are equal.
We use the parallel stream API to map both the association and the reference map.

features.id: A no-op operations returns the same instance!

extraInfo:
This test ensures that no-op operations like `putAll`, `retainAll`, `removeAll`... 
            do not create a new instance of the `Association` class, but rather return the same instance
            when passed an empty collection or set.

The result is still the same instance as the original association.

features.id: The spliterator of a sorted association preserves order during traversal. [0]

extraInfo:
The spliterator of a sorted `Association` must report the correct characteristics:
                - DISTINCT: Entries are unique
                - IMMUTABLE: Cannot be modified
                - SIZED: Knows exact size
                - NONNULL: Entries aren't null
                - ORDERED: The order according to the comparator

            Elements must be traversed in sorted order regardless of splitting.
            All entries should be traversed exactly once regardless of splitting strategy.
            It must support both sequential and parallel traversal, including splitting, 
            where parallel splitting should maintain global ordering.

blocks.text: A sorted association
We create a spliterator...
The characteristics include ORDERED, among other things:
We do a sequential traversal...
The elements are in ascending order!
We do a parallel-ready traversal with splitting
code: var consumer = { Pair<Integer, Integer> pair -> collectedBySplitting.add(pair) } as Consumer<Pair<Integer, Integer>>

blocks.text: Global order maintained despite splits
